10.1016/j.jechem.2022.02.010 Science Press and Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences Fig. 1 The hydrogen economy promises the sustainability of human society via the decarbonization of the hard-to-abate sections including industry, buildings, power generation, and transportations. Fig. 2 (a) Schematic illustration of the process flow for the water electrolysis technology. (b) The levelized price of hydrogen varies with the electricity price for the central polymer electrolyte membrane (PEM) electrolysis technology. (c) Reducing the overall potential of the electrolyzers could substantially lower the cost of the hydrogen in both the two-cents scenario and the renewable scenario for the central PEM electrolysis technology. (d) The levelized price of hydrogen varies with the electricity price for the distributed PEM electrolysis technology. (e) Reduction of the cell potential lowers the total price of hydrogen in both the two-cents scenario and the renewable scenario for the distributed PEM electrolysis. The results are estimated by the hydrogen analysis (H2A) model [29]. Fig. 3 Schematic illustration of the 2e-transfer involved electrocatalytic hydrogen evolution mechanism in the acidic and alkaline electrolytes. Typical Volmer-Heyrovsky mechanism and Volmer-Tafel mechanism are presented, which differ in the hydrogen formation step. Fig. 4 Schematic illustration of the electrocatalytic oxygen evolution mechanism in the acidic and alkaline electrolytes. The formation of oxygen molecules is achieved via either a direct combination of two EC-O intermediates or the decomposition of the EC-OOH intermediates. Fig. 5 Current parameter metric for the evaluation of the electrocatalytic HER/OER performance, including overpotentials at the current density of 10 mA cm−2 (η 10), Tafel slopes, stability, turnover frequency (TOF), mass activity (MA), specific activity (SA), electrochemically active surface area (ECSA). Fig. 6 Multiple strategies have been developed for achieving industry-scale current density by tailoring the structure of the electrocatalysts, which bridges the gap between the lab-scale investigations for the mechanism interpretation and fab-scale applications for commercialization of the water electrolysis technology. Optimized electrocatalytic performance can be realized via alloying, amorphization, doping, single-atom dispersion, and heterostructure constructions. Fig. 7 Significant perturbation of the electronic structures induces the accelerated reaction kinetics during the electrocatalytic process, thus enhancing the electrocatalytic performance towards hydrogen evolution, oxygen evolution, and overall water splitting. Fig. 8 (a) Summary of the electrocatalytic performance of the electrocatalysts in terms of the overpotential at the current density of 10 mA cm−2 and the Tafel slope towards hydrogen evolution reaction; (b) corresponding evaluation of the electrocatalytic activity under industrial relevant current densities in terms of the overpotentials at large current density (η LCD) and the stability duration. Fig. 9 Heterostructure represents a promising attempt for realizing highly efficient HER electrocatalysts under industry-relevant current densities by utilizing the synergy between the components. (a) HER polarization curve of MoS1.5Se0.5/NiCoSe2 in comparison with that of other catalysts including bare Ni foam, NiCoSe2, MoS2/NiCoSe2, and a Pt wire. (b) Durability tests for the MoS1.5Se0.5/NiCoSe2 heterostructure at fixed potentials of −57, −102, and −146 mV for response current densities of 10, 100, and 500 mA cm−2, respectively, over 25 h. Reproduced with permission [107]. Copyright 2020, American Chemical Society. (c) LSV curves for the samples in alkaline electrolyte. (d) Chronopotentiometry (CP) curves of edge-rich 1 T-MoS2 QS/Ni(OH)2 at HER current densities of 10, 100, and 500 mA cm−2 (denoted as CP10, CP100, and CP500, respectively), for 100 h. Reproduced with permission. Copyright 2020 [109], WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim. (e and f) LSV curves in 0.5 M H2SO4 and 1 M KOH for the electrocatalysts. Reproduced with permission [108]. Copyright 2018, WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim. Fig. 10 The introduction of heteroatoms into the matrix induces significant perturbation of electronic structures of the electrocatalysts, which optimizes the adsorption/desorption behavior of the key intermediates, thus boosting the electrocatalysis kinetics. (a) HER polarization curves for Co/Se-MoS2-NF under large current densities in comparison with 40% Pt/C and carbon paper. Co/Se-MoS2-NF and 40% Pt/C are drop-casted on carbon paper for measurements. (b) The chronopotentiometry measurements of long-term stability for Co/Se-MoS2-NF and 40% Pt/C at 1000 mA cm−2. (c) The adsorption free energies of H* (ΔG H*) at the in-plane, Mo-edge, and S-edge sites of pure, Co-doped, Se-doped, and Co/Se-codoped MoS2, denoted as MoS2, Co-MoS2, Se-MoS2, Co/Se-MoS2, respectively. Reproduced with permission [137]. Copyright 2020, Springer Nature. (d) HER polarization curves of carbon paper (CP), Mo2TiC2T x , Mo2TiC2T x -VMo, Mo2TiC2T x -PtSA, and Pt/C (40%), acquired using graphite rod as the counter electrode in 0.5 M H2SO4 solution. (e) Stability test of Mo2TiC2T x -PtSA through potential cycling, before and after 10,000 cycles. (f) Calculated charge density distribution differences between Mo2TiC2O2 and Mo2TiC2O2-PtSA. Reproduced with permission [75]. Copyright 2018, Springer Nature Limited. Fig. 11 (a) Summary of the electrocatalytic performance of the electrocatalysts in terms of the overpotential at the current density of 10 mA cm−2 and the Tafel slope towards oxygen evolution reaction; (b) corresponding evaluation of the electrocatalytic activity under industrial relevant current densities in terms of the overpotentials at large current density (η LCD) and the stability durations. Graphical abstract This review gives the insights into the various strategies for enhancement of the electrocatalytic performance of the catalysts and their significance in optimizing the electronics structures of the electrocatalysts for electrocatalytic water splitting at industrial scale. The green hydrogen generation powered by renewable electricity promises the potential decarbonization of the hard-to-abate sector and is essential for the fulfillment of the Paris Agreement that attempts to limit the global average temperature rise in the range of 1.5–2.0 °C above the pre-industrial level by the end of this century. Tremendous efforts have been devoted to the optimization of the electrocatalytic performance of the catalysts under industrial-relevant current densities via rational structure design, which induces a preferential electron distribution that favors the adsorption/desorption behavior of the key intermediates, thus accelerating the reaction kinetics. In this review, a brief introduction of the current energy status will be first presented to necessitate the importance of green hydrogen. Followed by the basic concepts and fundamental understanding of the reaction mechanisms, we present efficient strategies for the enhancement of the electrocatalytic performance of the catalysts to meet the rigorous requirement under industrial conditions and the in-depth understanding behind the reinforcement will be briefly discussed next. Then the recent advances regarding the rational design of electrocatalysts operating at an industrial scale will be summarized. Finally, the challenges and perspectives in this thriving field will be proposed from our point of view. Keywords Overall water splitting Industrial-scale current density Structural design Hydrogen evolution reaction Oxygen evolution reaction 1 Introduction The ever-rising demand for primary energy has caused the ever-increasing abundance of carbon dioxide (CO2) in the atmosphere, which has reached 418 ppm in 2019 [1]. To meet the climate target proposed in the Paris Agreement, which attempts to limit the global mean temperature rise to 1.5–2.0 °C in relation to the pre-industrial level by the end of this century, tremendous efforts have been devoted to the decarbonization of the present energy system. Hydrogen (H2), which serves as a versatile energy carrier for its zero-carbon emissions during usage, high energy density, feasible storage and transportation, and wide application for end-use scenarios, is enjoying unprecedented momentum from both policy-makers and commercial companies [2–4]. Over 95% of the hydrogen supply depends on the energy-intensive technique based on natural gas and coal, which is responsible for the CO2 emissions of approximately 830 Mt/year, necessitating the importance of the development of green hydrogen technology [5,6]. Powered by renewable electricity, the electrocatalytic water splitting serves as a low-carbon advantageous alternative for the generation of hydrogen at industrial scale to realize the decarbonization of hard-to-abate sections, including transport, aviation, industry, and buildings [1,7–9]. However, the high expense of hydrogen due to the unsatisfactory energy efficiency of the current water electrolysis technology has hampered the large-scale deployment of the promising strategy [10]. The overall water splitting (OWS) follows the reaction: 2H2O = 2H2 + O2, which implies the number of transfer electrons of two on the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) side and four on the oxygen evolution reaction side (OER) [11–14]. Further cost-down of the green hydrogen necessitates excellent electrocatalytic performance, including long-term stability and operation under industrial-relevant current densities for the electrochemical process. Great efforts have been devoted to the searching of novel electrocatalysts, including noble metals, oxides, sulfides, phosphides, selenides, carbon-based nanomaterials, etc., [15–20] and further optimization of the electrocatalysts via alloying, strain engineering, defect engineering, hybridization, amorphization, etc. [21–25]. More exposure of actives that favors the interaction between the active species and the intermediates and enhanced conductivity that accelerates the electron transport can be anticipated as a result of the rational structure design of the electrocatalysts [21]. More specifically, the tuned electronic structure of the electrocatalysts preferentially alters the adsorption/desorption behaviors of the key intermediates, lowers the energy barrier of the rate-determining step (RDS), and changes the RDS, and thus enhances the reaction kinetics during the electrocatalytic processes [24–27]. The fundamental understanding of the mechanism behind the electrochemical reactions and further evaluation of the electrocatalytic performance under industrial operation potentially promotes the advance of water electrolysis technology to at-scale deployment, and thus a comprehensive summary of the progress that has been achieved is necessary. Herein, in this review, we first rationalize the motivation towards the development of high-performance electrocatalysts for water splitting via a brief introduction of the present energy status and the necessity for lowering the cell voltage of the electrolyzers. The fllowing are the basic concepts, evaluation parameters and fundamental mechanisms behind HER and OER, which offers the readers an overall description of the water electrolysis technology. Then the strategies that are applied in boosting the reaction kinetics of the electrocatalytic processes and their significance in optimizing the electronics structures of the electrocatalysts are summarized. The recent progress that has been achieved in enhancing the electrocatalytic activity towards industrial conditions is comprehensively summarized. Finally, the challenges and perspectives in bridging the gap between the lab-scale investigations and fab-scale applications of the water electrolysis technique are presented from our point of view. 2 Fundamental concepts in the electrocatalytic water splitting 2.1 Overview The prosperity of human society has spurred the continuous growing demand for energy, which reaches 626.98 quadrillion British thermal units (or, quad BTUs, where 1 quad BTU = 293 TWh) in 2019, and is predicted to be 910.70 quad BTUs in 2050 [1]. Consequently, the energy-relevant CO2 emissions are estimated to increase from the current 35.33 Gt (2019) to 40.08 Gt (2050), causing the evident increase of the CO2 abundance to 411.28 ppm [1,28]. The ever-increasing concentration of greenhouse gases has urged the conclusion of the Paris Agreement, which prompts the policy-makers to limit the temperature increase to well below 2–1.5 °C by the end of this century via the major shift in electricity generation from the fossil-fuel-based scenario to the renewable source-based scenario [10]. As a promising energy carrier, hydrogen is now enjoying unprecedented momentum from both the government and business communities due to its versatile applications, storable features, energy-dense character, eco-friendliness, zero-carbon emissions for utilization, and reasonable price [1,5,8,9]. In fact, the demand for hydrogen has surged up to 70 million tons per year and most of it is consumed for oil refining and the production of ammonia [5]. Hydrogen is anticipated to be deployed at a large scale across all hard-to-abate sectors, including buildings, transport, power generation, industry, for the deep decarbonization of the current energy system (Fig. 1 ). Furthermore, the hydrogen production, conversion, and end-use across the energy system could potentially offer considerable interest for the job market by creating tremendous jobs and shaping the value chain for the hydrogen economy. More than 95% of today’s hydrogen is produced via an energy-intensive approach that depends heavily on traditional fossil fuels (i.e., natural gas and coal), which causes tremendous emissions of green-house gases [10]. Powered by renewable electricity, direct electrolysis of water has surged up as a promising alternative to conventional methods due to its unparalleled advantages. However, the expense of the hydrogen generated through the present electrolysis technology has hampered its large-scale deployment as a result of the high electricity prices and low technology readiness level. Great efforts have been devoted to the reduction of the high cost of green hydrogen via lowering the renewable electricity prices and improving the overall performance of the electrolyzers, thus a significant reduction of the price of green hydrogen can be anticipated in the near future. Here, we have predicted the future levelized prices of H2 based on the H2A production model [29], which offers transparent reporting of process design assumptions and a consistent cost analysis methodology for the production of H2 at central and distributed facilities [29,30] (Fig. 2 a). Most of the parameters are used as default in the H2A model and the cost of the hydrogen is estimated by varying the electricity prices and the overall cell potential with an operating current density of 1600 mA cm−2 for the PEM electrolysis technology. Furthermore, we have evaluated the influence of the cell voltages in the two-cents scenario and the ideal renewable scenario to rationalize the attempts for the development of high-performance electrocatalysts. Fig. 2(b and d) show the levelized prices of hydrogen as a result of the electricity prices at fixed cell potentials and voltage efficiency at the central and distributed facilities, which emphasizes the importance of the decrease of the electricity price. As shown in Fig. 2(b and d), usage of renewable electricity as the main feedstock reduces the overall cost of hydrogen to 4.48 and 6.24 dollars per kilogram ($/kgH2) at the central and distributed facilities, respectively, making it cost-competitive with the fossil-fuel-based counterpart. Increasing the voltage efficiency, which is defined as the ratio between the thermodynamical value for the water-splitting reaction and the applied potential of the electrolyzer, is another potential strategy for reducing the prices of the green hydrogen for both central and distributed electrolysis technologies (Fig. 2c and e). As illustrated, the levelized prices of H2 are estimated to be 7.25 and 4.35 $/kgH2 for the two-cent scenario and the renewable scenario if the cell voltage is set as 1.60 V and further decreased to 6.39 and 3.82 $/kgH2 under 1.40 V (Fig. 2c) for the central PEM electrolysis. In the case of the distributed PEM electrolysis, the levelized values of hydrogen are estimated to be 8.99 and 6.08 $/kgH2 for the two-cent scenario and the renewable scenario if the cell voltage reaches 1.60 V and is further lowered to 8.13 and 5.57 $/kgH2 with a potential bias of 1.40 V (Fig. 2e). In brief, at-scale deployment of water electrolysis technology requires further reduction of the H2 prices, and the harsh operation conditions under industrial operation necessitate the development of a highly efficient electrolyzer system with long-term stability and low cell voltage, which can be achieved by synergistically rational electrocatalyst design and electrolyzer design. 2.2 Reaction mechanism in the electrocatalytic hydrogen evolution The rational design of the electrocatalytic with desired performance demands a comprehensive understanding of the reaction process, which involves a complex interaction between the electrolyte, electrocatalysts, intermediates, product molecules, and the indispensable electrons [23,31]. Typically, the electrocatalytic HER process involves three elementary reactions (Fig. 3 ). The H2 formation may occur via the Volmer-Heyrovsky (V-H) pathway and the Volmer-Tafel (V-T) pathway. In the V-H route, the H2 is generated by the reaction of adsorbed hydrogen intermediates and protons (in the acid electrolyte) or water molecules (in alkali electrolyte), while the paired hydrogen intermediates directly combine on the surface of the electrocatalyst to evolve H2 in the V-T route (in both acid and alkali electrolytes) [21]. Under the acidic media, the adsorbed hydrogen intermediate (*H) is formed by adsorption of H+ on the catalyst surface (Volmer step, Equation (1)) [22,23,32], where * represents the active site. Then, the adsorbed *H combines with a proton and an electron to generate an adsorbed hydrogen molecule (Heyrovsky step, Equation (2)), which undergoes a subsequent desorption process and leaves the active site of the electrocatalyst [23]. Alternatively, H2 could be generated via the combination of two *H on the catalyst surface and then desorbs (Tafel step Equation (3)). Likewise, the reaction mechanism (V-H and V-T pathway) also applied to that in alkaline conditions, except for the H2O molecules as the source of protons. *H can be generated by the interaction of the electrocatalysts and water molecules in the alkaline electrolyte (Volmer step, Equation (4)). The formed *H also undergoes one of two different pathways: (i) the direct coupling of paired *H (Tafel step Equation (5)) or (ii) the obtained *H coupling with a proton from H2O, and achieves an electron to produce H2 (Heyrovsky step, Equation (6)), which desorbs from the surface of the electrocatalyst. Specifically, the reaction rate in acidic media is two to three orders of magnitude faster than that in alkaline solution, owing to the dissociation of H2O molecules. The change of the free Gibbs energy of the binding intermediate hydrogen (ΔG H*) is usually deemed as the most descriptor in estimating the electrocatalytic activity of the catalysts, which can be facially calculated through the density-functional-theory-based (DFT) methodology [33–36]. In acidic medium, (1) H + + EC + e - = EC - H ads (2) EC - H ads + H + + e - = EC + H 2 (3) 2 EC - H ads = 2 EC + H 2 In alkaline medium, (4) H 2 O + EC + e - = EC - H ads + OH - (5) 2 EC - H ads = 2 EC + H 2 (6) EC - H ads + H 2 O + e - = EC + OH - + H 2 2.3 Reaction mechanism in the electrocatalytic oxygen evolution Compared with the electrocatalytic HER process, the OER is a quite sluggish reaction kinetics due to involving multi-electron/proton processes for the final generation of oxygen molecules, hindering the energy efficiency of the overall water electrolysis process [24,25,37,38] (Fig. 4 ). The formation of reaction intermediates such as *OH, *O, *OOH is a prerequisite for OER, which may act as the rate-limiting step. Similar to that in the HER process, two distinct pathways for OER can be revealed in acidic and alkaline electrolytes (Fig. 4). For acidic OER, water molecules are first adsorbed on the active sites of the electrocatalysts via a one-electron oxidation process, generating an adsorbed *OH species (Equation (7)). Subsequently, an adsorbed oxo intermediate (*O) is formed via the oxidation of the *OH intermediate species (Equation (8)). The *O intermediates undergo two different pathways to form O2 molecules as follows: (i) the direct combination of paired *O species on the active site (Equation (9)) or (ii) the generation of *OOH intermediates via reacting with another water molecule (Equation (10)), which is oxidized by an electron transfer process to form adsorbed oxygen (Equation (11)) and then desorbs. Compared with acidic OER, the alkaline OER undergoes a similar reaction mechanism, where *OH intermediate is generated by consuming the hydroxyl ions in the alkaline solution (Equation (12)). Then, the *OH intermediate can be combined with another hydroxyl ion to form *O species by releasing an H2O molecule (Equation (13)). In a subsequent step, O2 is formed by direct coupling of two *O species (Equation (14)) or *O species participate in the production of *OOH coupling with OH− to desorb O2 (Equations (15) and (16)). In the OER process, multiple descriptors are applied in the theoretical investigations of the electrocatalytic oxygen evolution reaction, and the energy barrier for the RDS is commonly calculated and compared for reasoning the enhanced electrocatalytic performance of the electrocatalysts. Among the four elementary steps in the OER process, the formation of *OOH intermediates or decomposition of them is often deemed as the RDS, but there always exist exceptions, making the theory-guided design of high-performance OER nano-catalysts ambiguous. In acidic medium, (7) EC + H 2 O = EC - OH + H + + e - (8) EC - OH = EC - O + H + + e - (9) 2EC - O = 2EC + O 2 (10) EC - O + H 2 O = EC - OOH + H + + e - (11) EC - OOH = EC + O 2 + H + + e - In alkaline medium, (12) EC + OH - = EC - OH + e - (13) EC - OH + OH - = EC - O + H 2 O + e - (14) 2 EC - O = 2 EC + O 2 (15) EC - O + OH - = EC - OOH + e - (16) EC - OOH + OH - = EC + O 2 + H 2 O + e - 2.4 Evaluation of the electrocatalytic HER/OER performance As described above, the half-reactions (HER and OER) of water-splitting share some similarities, which offers the convenience for the construction of a toolbox for the evaluation of the electrocatalytic performance. Actually, for the comparison between different electrocatalysts, various parameters regarding the physical, chemical, and intrinsic activity have been proposed and validated for the rational design of highly efficient electrocatalysts towards HER, OER, and WS. Here in this subsection, the parameter matrix for the evaluation of the electrocatalytic performance of the nanocatalyst is briefly discussed (Fig. 5 ), including but not limited to the overpotentials at the current density of 10 mA cm−2 (η 10), Tafel slopes, stability, TOF, MA, SA, ECSA [12]. (1) Overpotential at the current density of 10 mA cm−2 (η 10) Based on the concept in the photovoltaic field, the overpotential required to achieve the current density of 10 mA cm−2, which corresponds to a 12.3% efficient solar water-splitting device [21], is now widely adopted as the simplest and most vital parameter to evaluate a water splitting catalyst. The overpotential is mainly caused by concentration polarization and electrochemical polarization, which can be significantly reduced by raising the working temperature, vigorously stirring, and using appropriate catalysts. Currently, the η 10 values for HER, OER, and overall water splitting are several millivolts to hundreds of millivolts, larger than 180 mV and 1.40–1.90 V, respectively. As evident as it is, a lower η 10 delivering high current density is desired, resulting in the high energy conversion efficiency. However, owing to several factors including the exposed active area and loading mass, η 10 is not regarded as a practical criterion for evaluating the intrinsic activity of the electrocatalyst. (2) Tafel slopes Tafel slope, derived from the polarization curves, expresses the dependence of the overpotential and current density, which is related to the intrinsic activity of the electrocatalysts. Generally, a lower Tafel slope value indicates achieving the same current density requires a smaller overpotential, which implies the faster reaction kinetics and facile electron transfer capability. According to the Butler-Volmer equation, the Tafel slope values of 120, 40, and 30 mV dec−1 indicate the Volmer, Heyrovsky, and Tafel steps, respectively, which enable the prediction of the reaction mechanisms during the electrocatalytic HER process [22,23]. Currently, the Tafel slopes in the previous reports exhibit similar values or even smaller ones with those of the noble-metal-based benchmarks, which reveals the fast kinetics of the state-of-art electrocatalysts. (3) Exchange current density (j 0) The interception of the Tafel slope when the overpotential reaches zero educes another index that is relevant to the intrinsic rate of electron transfer between the electrolytes and the electrocatalyst, namely the exchange current density (j 0). In a more complex form, the Tafel plot can be expressed in Equation (17), which clearly indicates the existence of the exchange current density. Typically, higher j 0 is required for high-performance electrocatalysts. (17) η = RT naF log j 0 - RT naF log j where R is the universal gas constant, T is the absolute temperature, F is the Faraday’s constant, n is the number of electron transfer. (4) TOF TOF, as a vital parameter to evaluate the intrinsic activity of the electrocatalysts, is defined as the number of products (H2 in HER, O2 in OER) that are generated per active site in unit time at a defined operation potential (Equation (18)). Evidently, higher TOF values indicate faster reaction kinetics and more outstanding intrinsic performance. Until now, how to precisely achieve TOF value still faces a great challenge. Nevertheless, the TOF values still represent a promising approach for comparing the catalytic activities among different catalysts, especially those similar systems. (18) TOF = jA α n F where j is the measured current density under specific overpotentials, A is the surface area, n is the transferred electron number to acquire the product, F is the Faraday’s constant. (5) MA or SA To eliminate the interferences from the different loading mass and the number of active sites, mass activity (mA mg−1) and specific activity (mA cm−2), which is defined as the current normalized by the loading mass and surface area of the electrocatalysts, respectively, are proposed. Higher MA/SA values are needed for the rational design of highly efficient electrocatalysts. (6) ECSA In a more intrinsic stage, the ECSA, which represents the area that is accessible to the electrolyte and takes part in the electrochemical conversion, is considered an important parameter for the evaluation of the electrocatalytic activity of the catalysts. Typically, the ECSA can be derived from the electrochemical measurement of the double-layer capacitance by the following Equation (19) (C s is the specific capacitance). More importantly, the ECSAs are encouraged to replace the geometric surface area or the electrode area to offer a more fundamental performance of the electrocatalysts in deciding the specific activity, turnover frequency, even η 10 and j 0. (19) ECSA = C dl C s (7) Stability Last but not least, long-term stability is another important parameter for the at-scale deployment. In a laboratory, there are two methods for the durability test, such as accelerated cyclic voltammetry and chronoamperometry or chronopotentiometry, which outlines the change of the current density or overpotential during the long-term test. Apparently, negligible alteration is required as evidence of the excellent stability of the electrocatalysts. Apart from the above-mentioned parameters, the Faradaic efficiency, double-layer capacitance, impendence, and turnover number are usually adopted for the characterization of the HER/OER electrocatalysts [39-41]. 3 Strategies for achieving industrial-scale current density towards water splitting 3.1 Overview Water electrolysis with zero carbon emission is an important strategy for the production of hydrogen with high purity and quantities [42,43]. Currently, alkaline and PEM electrolyzers are the most advanced and already commercial. At present, the industrial PEM water electrolysis operates with a cell voltage of 1.8–2.2 V to achieve 600–2000 mA cm−2 current density at cell temperature (50–80 °C). In addition, the system lifetime is usually 50–80 thousand hours and the working cell pressure is lower than 30 bar [44]. In 2050, there are some key performance parameters for the PEM electrolyser, in which overall water splitting needs a cell voltage below 1.7 V to reach 4–6 A cm−2 current density at the operating temperature of 80 °C and the system lifetime is as long as 100–120 thousand hours [45]. For industrial use, developing high-performance electrocatalysts plays a central role in electrochemical water splitting technology as it is closely related to practical applications. Operating cell voltage, which directly determines the energy consumption and electricity efficiency, is the first important parameter to be considered. The lower cell voltage required to produce equivalent hydrogen at the same current density indicates higher energy efficiency. The working current density relating to the energy efficiency is introduced as another important parameter for evaluating catalytic performance, which should be higher than the industrially-relevant current densities of 200 mA cm−2 [46]. The excellent catalytic activity of the electrocatalysts at industrial temperature (50–80 °C) [44], which are highly desirable, could veritably promote its practical water electrolysis applications. In addition. the long-term stability of the electrode materials, which is another vital parameter for commercial application, is highly required to the longevity of the electrolyzers, leading to reduced maintenance and operating costs from an economical point of view. More importantly, the facile and scaled-up preparation strategies are extremely needed to meet the industry-relevant developments. In order to realize the at-scale deployment of the electrolysis technology, various approaches have been proposed for the optimization of the electrocatalytic performance based on the parameter matrix. As it is a fact that the lab-scale investigations on the electrocatalytic performance of the electrocatalysts towards hydrogen evolution and oxygen evolution focus on the fundamental aspects of the electrocatalytic process, which emphasize the importance of η 10, Tafel slope, ECSA, TOF, and stability in a limited time (<1 week). Advanced characterization methods, including X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS), X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES), extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS), high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) and various in-situ/operando techniques offer sufficient and convincing information on the local environment of the active sites during the electrocatalytic reactions, leading to an impressive in-depth understanding of the mechanism behind the electron-transfer process [21,23,32]. In combination with modern computational methods (density-functional theory, molecular dynamics, Monte-Carlo, etc.), rational guiding principles for the intentional design of electrocatalysts with required activity, stability, and structure have been realized, at least to some extent [47–50]. Although much effort has been devoted to the lab-scale enhancement of the electrocatalyst performance via structural design (defect engineering, strain engineering, hybridization, alloying with the secondary element, etc.) [21], insufficient attention is paid to the research on the electrocatalytic performance of electrocatalysts under industrial current densities, which differs greatly from that under lab-scale conditions due to the vigorously changing local environment and different mass transport limitations. Herein, in this section, we emphasize the progress that has been made towards the at-scale deployment of electrolysis technology via structure design. As it is established that heterogeneous catalysis involves the adsorption of reactive molecules, diffusion to the active sites, a reaction process accompanied by bond breakage and reformation, and the desorption of the products from the surface of the electrocatalysts [51–53]. It is commonly accepted that the heterogeneous electrocatalytic catalysis process is sensitive to the structure of the electrocatalysts, electrolytes, applied potentials, and even the electrolyzer configurations. Among them, the structures at various scales of the electrocatalysts are intensively investigated, which induces the perturbation of the electronic structure that determines the reaction kinetics, thus influencing the electrocatalytic performance of the electrocatalysts. As mentioned above, the elementary steps during the hydrogen evolution and oxygen evolution process, among which the rate-determining step exists, are the key for enhancing the electrocatalytic activity of the electrocatalysts towards industrial water splitting. Rational structure design that evokes preferential electron distribution is critical for the realization of the desired electrocatalytic performance while delivering commercially relevant current densities. As illustrated in Fig. 6 , multiple strategies, including alloying, amorphization, doping, single-atom dispersion, and heterostructure construction, have been successfully exploited in achieving industrial-scale current density and excellent stability in the meantime, which bridges the gap between the lab-scale investigations and fab-scale applications. Herein, in this section, a discussion on the importance of unique structures will be presented. 3.2 Alloying The combination of metals or metals with other elements generates alloys, which exhibit unique physical/chemical properties and have been widely investigated in electrocatalytic reactions, including oxygen reduction reactions, CO2 reduction reactions, nitrogen reduction reactions, hydrogen evolution reactions, and oxygen evolution reactions [54]. The synergy between the components could potentially accelerate the reaction kinetic and thus enhance the electrocatalytic performance by optimizing the electron distribution towards a favorable adsorption/desorption behavior of the key intermediates. Yin et al. [55] reported the alloying of iron and iridium, which delivers outstanding electrocatalytic performance towards both OER and HER, with overpotentials of 200 and 16.6 mV to achieve the current density of 20 mA cm−2. Further investigation reveals its excellent stability in the two-electrode electrolysis test, which shows a negligible decline for over 500 h under the current density of 150 mA cm−2. Due to the thermal-shock-induced dislocations in the IrNi nanoalloys, Hu et al. [56] prepared a highly efficient electrocatalyst for HER with only 17 mV to reach the current density of 10 mA cm−2, which is attributed to the shift of the ΔG H* towards the optimal region due to the structural change. Schuhmann et al. [57] have discovered the scaling relationship between the activation energy (E a) towards OER and the nearest Ni-Ni interatomic distance (d Ni-Ni), which can be affected via alloying with other elements. Further evidence indicates that the electron transfer towards the Ni species lowers the E a, and hence the adsorption/desorption energies of the intermediates, thus affecting the OER performance of the electrocatalyts. Currently, various challenges still exists for the development of alloy catalysts. Especially, the fabrication strategies are rather complex or not general methods, the structural information has not been sufficiently revealed, and the complicated catalytic mechanism has not been deeply clarified. 3.3 Amorphism The introduction of atom disorder into the crystal lattice represents an alternative approach to boost the electrocatalytic performance of the electrocatalyst by improving the conductivity of the nanomaterials, exposing abundant uncoordinated sites that act as active sites, and changing the local environment around the active species. Furthermore, compared with the crystalline catalysts, the amorphous catalysts of the same composition show outstanding stability owing to the structural flexibility and self-healing capacity. Wu et al. [58] reported the amorphization of the NiFe-LDH via doping boron into the lattice, which shows outstanding electrocatalytic activity towards oxygen evolution with required overpotentials of 151, 286, 381 mV to deliver the current densities of 100, 500, 1000 mA cm−2. Zou et al. [59] investigated the formation process of Ni-Fe bimetallic hydroxide, which exhibits excellent electrocatalytic activity for OER at the current density of 1000 mA cm−2 in the alkaline electrolyte due to the synergy of high electronic conductivity, excellent structural stability, and efficient electrocatalytic reactivity. Hierarchically amorphous (Ni-Fe)S x /NiFe(OH) y with unique nanostructures has been proven as a promising bifunctional electrocatalyst for the water electrolysis, which requires overpotentials of only 124 and 290 mV to reach 100 mA cm−2 in the alkaline medium and 1.46 V to achieve 10 mA cm−2 for the overall water splitting process, as reported by Li et al. [60]. Thanks to the disordered atomic structure of the amorphous catalysts, it is hard to acquire the precise structure information using normal characterization equipment (for example, X-ray diffraction) and the catalytic mechanism has not been clearly clarified on an atomic level. 3.4 Doping Incorporation of heteroatoms into the lattices induces the breakage of the long-range periodicity of the atoms, and thus the perturbation of the electron distributions, which often results in the preferential enhancement of the electrocatalytic performance [39]. In recent years, great breakthroughs on heteroatoms doped electrocatalysts have been obtained by doping metallic elements (Fe, Co, Ni, etc.) and nonmetallic elements (N, P, S, O, etc.) [61]. Generally, the influence of doping effect on catalytic performance could be controlled by regulating the type, configuration, and concentration of the hetero-dopants. For the metallic heteroatom with rich electrons, they can not only improve the electrical conductivity of the catalysts, but also optimize the ΔG H* by altering the local electron structure [62,63]. Lou et al. [64] argued that the doping of Fe atoms into the octahedral sites of Co3O4 could potentially enhance the electrocatalytic activity for the OER with an overpotential of 260 mV at the current density of 10 mA cm−2 and a low Tafel slope of 43 mV dec−1, which is attributed to the reduction of the energy barrier for the RDS (EC-OH + OH−=EC-O + H2O + e− in this case) due to the dopant. As suggested by Zhao et al. [65], the covalently doped Co atom in the MoS2 can induce the bifunctionality of the nanomaterial, which exhibits superior electrocatalytic activity with overpotentials of 48 and 260 mV to achieve 10 mA cm−2 for the HER and OER process in the basic electrolyte. Further DFT-based calculations indicate the transformation of the electrocatalyst from the semiconductor to the metallic state, which is beneficial for electrocatalytic reactions. Li and co-workers [66] demonstrated that the Cu doped MoS2/rGO electrocatalysts display an outstanding activity and durability for the HER with reduced onset potential, enhanced exchange current density, and a Tafel slop as small as 90 mV dec−1 under acid condition, originating from the synergistic effect between edge-exposed MoS2 and Cu. In recent study, Pt/Ni-doped RuO2 frame shell with highly reactive surfaces obviously improves the catalytic activity for the OER process in acidic media, reaching a current density of 10 mA cm−2 at an overpotential of 239 mV, which is ascribed to the facile formation of active species owing to the presence of dopants, and a highly open frame structure [67]. Meanwhile, via the doping of a series of nonmetallic elements, the electrocatalytic activity toward HER and OER has been significantly improved by modulating the electronic structure of the catalysts and optimizing the ΔG H*. Chai et al. [68] reported the introduction of P into the inverse spinel Fe3O4, which delivers the current density of 100 mA cm−2 under the overpotential of 138 mV in alkali. Further computational results ascribe the excellent electrocatalytic activity to the optimized ΔG H* and the unconventional dissociation mechanism. With N incorporation, the as-achieved N-CoP/CC catalysts present outstanding HER activity with low overpotentials of 74, 39, and 25 mV to achieve current density of 10 mA cm−2 in PBS (phosphate buffer solution), acidic, and alkaline media, respectively. The further theoretical calculations demonstrate that the superior catalytic activity is attributed to the reduced electronic density of Co d-orbital and the optimal ΔG H* value with N-doping [69]. Elemental doping has been proved to be a pivotal way for adjusting the electronic structure, improving the wettability properties, lowering the kinetic energy barrier, and creating more active sites. Nevertheless, several factors should be carefully addressed during the preparation of the catalysts, such as the fine control of the doping amount and the clean surface of the catalysts electrode after the doping treatment. 3.5 Heterostructure Construction of heterointerfaces is an efficient approach to boost the electrocatalytic performance of the electrocatalyst due to the synergy between the two distinct components, which induces the electron transfer between them and perturbation of the electronic structures of the active species. Zhao et al. [70] reported the preparation of the Ni2P/NiTe2 heterostructure and further electrochemical evaluation indicates the excellent electrocatalytic activity for the HER in the alkaline electrolyte with an overpotential of only 62 mV to achieve the current density of 10 mA cm−2. Computational results reveal the preferential electron transfer from the Ni atoms to the *H at the interface, which enhances the binding strength of the adsorbed hydrogen intermediate and thus lowers the kinetic barrier for the water dissociation process. Hu et al. [71] reported the generation of atomic-level interfaces in the NiSe2/CoSe2 heterostructure, which exhibits superior electrocatalytic activity for oxygen evolution with an overpotential of 286 mV to deliver the current density of 10 mA cm−2. Further experimental and theoretical investigations attribute the high activity to the lowered oxidation overpotential for the Ni and Co species and the electronic interaction between the inner Se atoms and external hydroxide/oxide species, which synergistically reduces the energy barrier for the OER and accelerates the reaction kinetics. Xu et al. [72] prepared the two-dimensional CoNC@Co2N heterostructure via the space-confined approach, which requires 1.52 V for the two-electrode electrolyzer to deliver 10 mA cm−2 and exhibits high stability during the long-term test that lasts 280 h. In addition, more specific surface areas with exposed active sites, and better durability are highly desirable for electrocatalysts. Constructing the unique interface structures in heterostructure materials, which have a great contribution to make to excellent catalytic performance, faces grand challenges. 3.6 Single-atom catalyst Aiming for the maximum utilization rate of the active atoms, atomically dispersed metals on the substrate have been thriving as a promising strategy for addressing the issues in multifarious energy storage and conversion devices by combining the advantages of both heterogeneous and homogeneous catalysts. The single-atom catalysts demonstrate the highest atom utilization efficiency and mass activity for catalysis [73]. Moreover, they exhibit excellent stability by forming strong chemical bonds with the support materials [74]. Wang et al. [75] successfully anchored the atomic Pt species onto the Mo2TiC2T x substrate due to the immobilization of Mo vacancies and prepared the Mo2TiC2T x -PtSA electrocatalyst, which delivers small overpotentials of 30 and 77 mV to achieve the current density of 10 and 100 mA cm−2 and 40-fold enhancement of the mass activity in comparison with commercial Pt/C. DFT-based calculations attribute the excellent HER activity to the delocalization of the electrons of the Pt atoms, which results in the d-electron density around the Fermi level and thus leads to the enhanced electrocatalytic performance. By dispersing isolated Ru atoms on the CoFe-LDH, Sun et al. [76] obtained the Ru/CoFe-LDH electrocatalyst that requires 198 mV to achieve the current density of 10 mA cm−2 with a Tafel slope of 39 mV dec−1. Further investigations confirm the existence of the oxidation state of 4+ for the Ru species and a reduced energy barrier for the rate-determining step (EC-O + OH−=EC-OOH + e− in this case), which contributes to the excellence of the Ru/CoFe-LDH electrocatalyst. Chen et al. [77] reported the preparation of nitrogen-doped carbon (NPC) with atomically dispersed Fe species, in which the Fe-N4 configuration serves as the active site. The Fe-N4 SAs/NPC requires 1.67 V to reach the current density of 10 mA cm−2 in the two-electrode setup, which can be rationalized by the reduced energy barrier of the RDS (EC-O + OH−=EC-OOH + e− in this case) in the OER process and optimized binding energy of the hydrogen intermediate in the HER process. However, noble metals of particularly small size have the tendency to aggregate into larger particles at elevated temperature due to their excess surface free energy, which will result in reduced catalytic reactivity or even deactivation. 4 Significance of the optimized electronic structure 4.1 Overview The unique structural characteristics bring a unique electronic structure, which is directly related to the electrocatalytic activity due to the changed intrinsic adsorption/desorption behaviors of the key intermediates [21]. As discussed in our previous work, the unique structural design that introduces the interruption of the periodicity of the crystal structure exhibits a significant influence on the electronic structure of the electrocatalysts, which preferentially accelerates the reaction kinetics and enhances the electrocatalytic performance for hydrogen evolution and oxygen evolution by exposing abundant active species that access the reactive species and increases the conductivity that facilitates the electron transfer. More specifically, the improved electrocatalytic performance is often related to the tailoring of the electronic structure, which involves (I) generation of an intermediate band due to the existence of the heteroatoms, (II) variation of d-band position, and (III) reduction of the bandgap. The change of the electron distribution of the electrocatalysts induces (I) optimized adsorption energy for the key intermediate (*H in the case of HER), (II) decrease of the energy barrier for the rate-determining step, and (III) even the change of the rate-determining step [21] (Fig. 7 ). Herein, a detailed discussion regarding the influence on the electronic structures induced by the above-mentioned strategies will be presented. 4.2 Generation of intermediate band The introduction of the breakage of the periodicity of the crystal lattices causes a significant perturbation of the electron distribution, which may generate new electronic states in the band alignment of the electrocatalyst, thus boosting the electrocatalytic performance. Wang et al. [78] reported the filling of oxygen vacancies with phosphorus in the Co3O4 lattice and generated the P-Co3O4 electrocatalysts. Theoretical investigations on the band structure of P-Co3O4 reveal the appearance of new electronic states near the Fermi level, which potentially shifts the ΔG H* to the optimal region and reduces the energy barrier to 0.39 eV for the rate-determining step (EC-OOH + OH−=EC + O2 + H2O + e− in this case). Further electrochemical evaluation indicates the superior electrochemical activity for both HER and OER with small overpotentials of 120 and 280 mV to achieve the current density of 10 mA cm−2, and low Tafel slope values of 52 and 51.6 mV dec−1, respectively. 4.3 Variation of d-band position The d-band theory, which states that the d-band center relative to the Fermi level governs the determination of the interaction energy between the adsorbate and electrocatalytic sites, is often applied in oxygen-related reactions [79–85]. The upshift or downshift of the d-band position implies the enhancement or weakening of the binding strength of the intermediates to the transition-metal-based electrocatalysts, which subsequently alters the reaction kinetics [86–94]. Substitution of nickel atoms with iron species in the Ni2P lattice induces the upshift of the d-band center to the Fermi level, which leads to the balance among the oxygen-containing intermediates during the electrocatalytic oxygen evolution reaction, thus reducing the energy barrier for the rate-determining step (EC-O + OH−=EC-OOH + e− in this case) to 1.24 eV, as reported by Chen et al. [95]. The obtained (Ni x Fe1− x )2P requires only 166 mV to achieve the current density of 10 mA cm−2 with a Tafel slope of 59.3 mV dec−1. Wang et al. [96] introduced vanadium as a dopant into the crystal lattice of the Co4N matrix, which causes the downshift of the d-band center of the V-Co4N, facilitating the adsorption of the hydrogen intermediate. The electrocatalytic hydrogen evolution test in the alkaline electrolyte indicates the outstanding activity of V-Co4N with a low overpotential of 37 mV to reach 10 mA cm−2 and a small Tafel slope of 44 mV dec−1. 4.4 Reduction of the bandgap It is well documented that the bandgap of the semiconductor is directly related to the conductivity, which can be described as σ = A exp (−E g/2 kT) (where σ represents the conductivity, E g is the bandgap) [21]. Due to the reduced bandgap, higher carrier concentration and enhanced electronic conductivity can be anticipated, which potentially favors the electrocatalytic reactions. Hou et al. [97] constructed the shell/core NC/Vo-WON heterostructure, which realizes the transition of the electrocatalysts from the semiconductor nature to the metallic feature. The enhanced conductivity and favorable electronic structure that facilitates the hydrogen adsorption synergistically contribute to the excellent electrocatalytic activity with only 16 mV for the current density of 10 mA cm−2 and a low Tafel slope of 33 mV dec−1. Combined experimental and theoretical results confirm the narrowing of the bandgap after doping with sulfur atoms into the CoO, as proposed by Deng et al. [98]. The introduction of sulfur atoms causes the accumulation of electrons along the Co-O direction, which optimizes the binding strength of the oxygen-containing intermediates and promotes the electron transfer, obtaining a highly efficient electrocatalyst with 66 mV to achieve 10 mA cm−2 and a low Tafel slope of 63.9 mV dec−1. 5 Advances in the structure design to achieve an industrial current density 5.1 Overview As discussed above, numerous strategies have been applied in improving the electrocatalytic performance of the electrocatalyst for hydrogen evolution, oxygen evolution, and water splitting under industrial-relevant current densities. The distortion of the lattice due to the introduction of atom irregularity induces the perturbation of the electronic structure of the electrocatalysts, through which the reaction kinetic during the electrochemical reactions is accelerated, thus enhancing the electrocatalytic activity of the electrocatalysts [21]. Based on the mechanism of electrocatalytic water splitting under different electrolytes, the type of electrolytes has a great influence on the catalytic activity of the electrocatalysts and the commercial availability of hydrogen. Acidic electrolytes with enough protons are beneficial to the HER process. Moreover, acidic water electrolysis versus alkaline water splitting shows clear advantages of high-pressure compatibility, high-current density, and simplicity, expanding the application scope of water electrolysis. However, the activity of water electrolysis in acidic media will drop sharply due to the strong corrosion of acidic environment for electrocatalysts, and the noble metal electrocatalysts with good corrosion resistance are usually needed, which will further increase the investment cost. Although splitting water into H2 and O2 is discovered in acidic media, overall water splitting for large-scale industrial applications is mainly performed in alkaline electrolytes for over a century [99]. Furthermore, non-noble metal electrocatalysts display relative durability and avoid corrosion and dissolution in alkaline electrolytes. Alkaline electrolyzers can produce high purity hydrogen and the hydrogen production capacity is several times higher than that of PEM electrolyzers. Compared with water splitting in the acidic electrolyte, alkaline water splitting, which works at lower pressure levels under higher temperatures, has obvious advantages for large-scale and low-cost hydrogen production. However, the most prominent issue of overall water splitting in alkaline media is the low current density owing to the enhanced Ohmic loss and requires an additional water dissociation step, which needs an accessional energy barrier and affects the total reaction kinetics. So far, various kinds of catalysts have been synthesized to catalyze HER and OER efficiently in acidic, alkaline, and neutral electrolytes, including carbon-based catalysts, transition-metal-based catalysts, and noble metal-based catalysts [100–102]. Among these electrocatalysts, Ru/Ir-based materials with their high activity and good stability have been considered as the state-of-the-art catalysts for OER, and Pt-group metals exhibit extraordinary electrocatalytic performance for HER, in alkaline or acidic media. For RuO2 and IrO2 catalysts, typical overpotentials of ∼300 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm−2 are required for the OER process in the acidic environment [103,104]. Considering their scarcity and cost issue of noble metal catalysts, layered hydroxides, mixed-metal oxides, and non-oxide catalysts have been widely reported and regarded as low-cost alternatives for Ru and Ir oxides. And vast earth-abundant HER catalysts candidates, including transition metals (Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, etc.) and nonmetals (B, C, N, P, etc.), have been designed and explored for constructing HER electrocatalysts [102]. Herein, in this section, recent advances on the rational structure design for the realization of industrial current densities towards HER, OER, and OWS under acidic and alkaline media are summarized. 5.2 Hydrogen evolution reaction under industrial condition The electrocatalytic hydrogen evolution follows the reaction of 2H++2e−=H2 in the acidic electrolyte and 2H2O = H2 + 2OH−+2e− in the alkaline electrolyte. As discussed in the previous section, the electrocatalytic HER proceeds via the V-H or the V-T mechanism based on the binding strength of the key intermediates on the active sites. Strategies, including establishing heterostructures, doping, amorphization, and constructing SACs represent the most effective approaches for the preparation of high-performance electrocatalysts that can behave efficiently under industrial current densities [58,105–140] (Fig. 8 ). Electrochemical evaluation under relatively small current densities reveals the efficacy of the attempts for the optimization of the electrocatalytic performance of the catalysts (Fig. 8a). Further evaluation of the electrocatalytic activity of the electrocatalysts under large current densities witnesses the progress that has been achieved for the at-scale application of the water electrolysis technology with low overpotential and excellent long-term stability (Fig. 8b). Herein, in this section, we provide a comprehensive introduction of the recent achievements regarding the optimization of the electrocatalysts to fulfill the requirements of the industry. The construction of heterostructures allows the combination of multiple advantages of distinct components and the electron transfer between them, which could potentially accelerate the reaction kinetics, thus enhancing the electrocatalytic performance. Zhou et al. [107] reported the synthesis of a hierarchical MoS1.5Se0.5/NiCoSe2 hybrid electrocatalyst, which exhibits excellent electrocatalytic activity for HER in the acidic electrolyte with low overpotentials of 57, 88, and 102 mV to achieve the current density of 10, 50, and 100 mA cm−2, respectively (Fig. 9 a). Further stability test under industrial current density (500 mA cm−2) reveals its superior durability of the heterostructured catalyst for 25 h (Fig. 9b). The enhanced HER performance stems from the synergy between the layered MoS1.5Se0.5 nanoparticles and the conductive NiCoSe2 support. To accelerate the HER kinetics in the alkaline electrolyte, Song et al. [109] proposed the construction of the edge/edge hybrid that consists of 1T-MoS2 and Ni(OH)2. Benefited from the unique structure, the 1T-MoS2 QS/Ni(OH)2 electrocatalysts show boosted reaction kinetics, which is validated by both the theoretical and experimental results with low overpotentials of 57 and 112 mV to reach the current density of 10 and 100 mA cm−2 (Fig. 9c). Further stability evaluation indicates excellent durability for as long as 100 h at current densities up to 500 mA cm−2 (Fig. 9d). Shen et al. [108] successfully prepared the Ni2P/Fe2P hybrid via transforming nickel hydroxide into a 3D Prussian blue analogue array that exhibits outstanding electrocatalytic HER performance in both acidic and alkaline electrolytes. Electrochemical evaluation of the electrocatalysts indicates the superior activity of 70 and 121 mV to achieve 10 mA cm−2 in acid and alkali, respectively (Fig. 9e and f), and it requires only 266 mV to reach 500 mA cm−2 in the acidic medium. The atom disorder that exists in the crystalline lattices induces tremendous unsaturated atoms, dangling bonds, which serve as active species during the electrocatalysis process by larger exposure of active sites and elevated conductivity, thus boosting the reaction kinetics [58,118,129,139]. Wu et al. [58] reported the boron-induced amorphization of the crystalline layered double hydroxides (LDHs), which exhibits outstanding electrocatalytic HER activity under large current densities. Due to the advantages of the amorphism, the amorphous NiCo-LDH that supported on the Ni foam (A-NiCo-LDH/NF) yields low overpotentials of 151, 286, and 381 mV to achieve the current density of 100, 500, and 1000 mA cm−2 in the alkaline electrolyte, which outperforms the commercial Pt/C electrocatalysts, indicating its potential in the at-scale application in the future industries. Further electrocatalytic evaluation indicates its superior stability for as long as 72 h. The incorporation of heteroatoms into the crystal lattices of the electrocatalysts represents a facile and efficient approach for optimizing the electrocatalytic performance of the catalysts, which have been adopted in the exploit of the NRR, ECR, HER, and OER electrocatalysts. Deng et al. [137] have successfully confined the Se and Co atoms into the MoS2 support, which delivers outperforming electrocatalytic activity towards HER under large current density. The Co/Se-MoS2-NF electrocatalysts require 382 mV to achieve the current density of 1000 mA cm−2, which is superior to the commercial Pt/C catalyst (Fig. 10 a). Further electrochemical evaluation indicates its excellent stability for as long as 360 h (Fig. 10b). DFT-based calculations ascribe the enhanced electrocatalytic activity to the balance between the enhancement effect of Co-doping and the weakening effect of Se-doping on the adsorption of the hydrogen intermediates, which leads to the moderate ΔG H* to the optimal region, thus enhancing the reaction kinetics (Fig. 10c). The atomically dispersed transition metal atoms on the substrate offer the maximum utilization rate of the atoms by bridging the gap between the heterogeneous and homogeneous catalysis, which is now thriving as a promising approach for addressing the problems encountered in energy storage and conversion processes. Wang et al. [75] anchored the Pt atoms onto the double transition metal MXene nanosheets, which offers prominent electrocatalytic activity towards HER with only 30 and 77 mV to deliver 10 and 100 mA cm−2 (Fig. 10d). The Mo2TiC2T x -PtSA electrocatalyst shows outstanding stability after 10,000 CV cycles and negligible degradation of the overpotential can be observed, which is also validated by the chronoamperometry evaluation (Fig. 10e). DFT-based results reveal the electron delocalization around the Pt atoms, which implies the redistribution of the electrons after the anchoring of the heteroatoms (Fig. 10f). Further projected density of states (PDOS) analysis indicates higher occupied states near the Fermi level, which is associated with the enhanced conductivity of the electrocatalyst (Fig. 10g). The optimized electronic structure of the Mo2TiC2T x -PtSA leads to the optimal adsorption energy for the key intermediates during the HER process, which is related to the faster formation and release of H2, and thus boosting the HER kinetics (Fig. 10h). For a comprehensive understanding of the recent advances that have been achieved regarding the hydrogen evolution reactions under industrial-relevant current densities via multiple design strategies, a summary of the electrocatalytic performance of the representative electrocatalysts is provided in Table 1 . 5.3 Oxygen evolution reaction under industrial condition The electrocatalytic oxygen evolution evolves through 2H2O = O2 + 4H++4e− in the acidic media, or 4OH−=O2 + 2H2O + 4e− in the alkaline electrolyte, which involves the four-electron transfer. It is well accepted that the sluggish reaction kinetics hinders the overall energy efficiency of water electrolysis, which requires further acceleration, and various approaches, including the construction of heterostructures, amorphization, doping, etc., have been adopted [142,154–192]. The tuned electronic structure guarantees the reduced energy barrier for the rate-determining step, favorable adsorption/desorption behavior of the key intermediates, thus boosting the reaction kinetics during the electrochemical process. An electrochemical test in the alkaline electrolyte reveals the optimal activity towards OER under limited current density (Fig. 11 a). The evaluation under industrial-relevant conditions further validates the important role of the optimization strategies exhibiting low overpotential under 500/1000 mA cm−2 and superior long-term durability (Fig. 11b). Herein, in this section, we briefly introduce the advances that have been achieved in accelerating the reaction kinetics on the OER side. Similar to the case in the HER process, the hetero-interfaces have proven their efficacy in optimizing the electrocatalytic OER performance under industrial current densities. Li et al. report the construction of the NiTe/NiS nanointerfaces via the ion-exchange approach, which delivers the current density of 100 mA cm−2 at the overpotential of 287 mV and a Tafel slope of 49 mV dec−1 in the alkaline electrolyte (Fig. 12 a). Theoretical evidence indicates the reduced energy barrier for the rate-determining step (EC-O + OH = EC-OOH + e− in this case) is due to the formation of the interface between the NiTe and NiS (Fig. 12b). Further DOS analysis shows the shift of the d-band center for the NiTe/NiS to the lower energy, which is responsible for the weakened binding strength for the oxygen-containing intermediates, and is consistent with the experimental results (Fig. 12c). Breaking the periodic atoms into disordered counterparts, which is accompanied by the formation of numerous uncoordinated sites and a decrease of the resistance, represents an alternative method for the construction of efficient OER electrocatalysts. Zou et al. [59] proposed the preparation of the Ni-Fe-OH@Ni3S2/NF electrocatalyst with being covered by the amorphous Ni-Fe bimetallic hydroxide species on the surface. The presence of the amorphous phase in the electrocatalyst favors the OER process, and the Ni-Fe-OH@Ni3S2/NF shows low overpotentials of 370, 469, and 565 mV to achieve 500, 1000, and 1500 mA cm−2, respectively (Fig. 12d). The Ni-Fe-OH@Ni3S2/NF exhibits excellent stability under harsh conditions of 500 mA cm−2 in 1 M KOH and 1000 mA cm−2 in 30 wt% KOH for as long as 50 h (Fig. 12e and f). The enhanced electrocatalytic activity of HER is attributed to the synergistic effects between the structural and catalytic advantages of amorphous Ni-Fe-OH and Ni3S2 nanosheet arrays. Via incorporation of oxygen atoms into the Ni-Fe-S (NFS) ultrathin nanosheets, Zhang et al. [165] prepared the O-NFS-ECT electrocatalyst with amorphous features followed by electrochemical tuning. The O-NFS-ECT only requires an overpotential of 300 mV to achieve the current density of 500 mA cm−2, outperforming the commercial RuO2 counterpart (Fig. 12g). Great stability of the O-NFS-ECT can be demonstrated after testing for 12 h at the current density of 1100 mA cm−2 (Fig. 12h). More impressively, the O-NFS-ECT demonstrates a Faradaic efficiency of 100% towards the electrocatalytic oxygen evolution reaction (Fig. 12i). As illustrated by tremendous researches, the sluggish reaction kinetics on the OER side hampers the overall energy efficiency of the overall water electrolysis set-up, and thus great efforts have been devoted to the development of efficient electrocatalysts for the anodic reactions. Cheng et al. [192] reported the electrosynthesis of metal hydroxides/oxides on the support, which exhibits superior hydrophilic/aerophobic performance due to the enhanced electrodeposit-support interface as a result of the insertion of the nitrate anions into the graphene layer (Fig. 13 a). The obtained NiCeO x H y /G electrocatalyst exhibits enhanced OER kinetics with small overpotentials of 177 and 500 mV at the current density of 10 and 3000 mA cm−2 (Fig. 13b). Further stability evaluation indicates excellent durability for as long as 300 h at the current density of 1000 mA cm−2 (Fig. 13c). The integration of ceria in nickel hydroxide promotes the preferential exposure of the (003) facet of γ-NiOOH, which optimizes the electronic structure of the electrocatalysts, and thus enhances the OER performance. Controlled iron corrosion induces the well-oriented, boundary-rich morphology on the substrate, which represents a cost-effective approach for the construction of an excellent OER electrocatalyst under industrial current density, as reported by Zou et al. [190] (Fig. 13d). The obtained 3D-O2-Cat-1 electrocatalyst delivers current densities of 500 and 1000 mA cm−2 at the overpotentials of 300 and 340 mV in the alkaline electrolyte (Fig. 13e). Furthermore, the concentrated electrolyte promises the reduction of overpotentials to 257 and 280 mV to afford the same current density. More importantly, the electrocatalyst is stable for 5000 and 1050 h in 1 M and 10 KOH media under a current density of 1000 mA cm−2, which shows promising potential for the at-scale application of the material (Fig. 13f). Zou et al. [173] reported the solid-state boronizing method that produces boronized metal sheets using various commercial metals (Fig. 13g). The as-prepared boronized NiFe alloy exhibits an overpotential of 270 mV to deliver the current density of 10 mA cm−2 and is stable for as long as 3000 h (Fig. 13h). Compared with their counterparts, the boronized NiFe alloys show outperforming stability and corrosion resistivity under 500 mA cm−2, proving their potential for commercialization (Fig. 13i). Notably, the active species is estimated to be the amorphous, metaborate-containing oxyhydroxide on the surface of the electrocatalyst. For a better comparison of the electrocatalytic performance of the electrocatalysts under industrial-relevant current densities, a summary of the representative catalysts that were recently reported is presented in Table 2 . 5.4 Overall water splitting under the industrial condition Combining the HER and OER, the overall water splitting follows the reaction 2H2O = O2 + 2H2, which requires a thermodynamic potential of 1.23 V. Aiming for the commercialization of water electrolysis technology, tremendous efforts have been devoted to lowering the cell voltages, accelerating the reaction kinetics, and searching for cost-effective electrocatalysts via rational structural design [55,60,68,143–150,193-201,207–228], whose efficacy has been confirmed by recent achievements (Fig. 14 ). Herein, in this section, the recent progress regarding the enhancement of the overall water splitting under large current densities will be briefly discussed. Two-dimensional and three-dimensional imperfections induce a significant perturbation of the electron distribution, which favors electron transfer and optimizes the adsorption/desorption behavior of the key intermediates, and thus boosts the electrocatalytic reaction kinetics. Ren et al. [198] report the preparation of the Fe-Ni-P hybrid electrocatalyst, which requires 1.42 V to achieve the current density of 10 mA cm−2 and a low Tafel slope of 69.2 mV dec−1 (Fig. 15 a). Furthermore, the FeP/Ni2P catalyst affords the current densities of 100, 500, and 1000 mA cm−2 when the applied potentials are 1.60, 1.72, and 1.78 V, respectively (Fig. 15b). Chronopotentiometric test for more than 40 h confirms its excellent stability under the current density of 500 mA cm−2 (Fig. 15c). Li et al. [144] constructed a unique nanostructure that consists of graphdiyne and sandwiched iron/cobalt LDHs, which delivers current densities of 500 and 1000 mA cm−2 with applied potentials of 1.48 and 1.49 V in a two-electrode water electrolysis device due to the facile electronic interaction and electron transfer between the components (Fig. 15d and e). DFT-based results indicate a lower energy barrier for the rate-determining step during the OER and HER processes, which contributes to the boosted reaction kinetics during the water dissociation reaction. The e-ICLDH@GDY also exhibits superior stability for over 60 h at the current density (Fig. 15f). The generation of amorphous phases in the catalyst is demonstrated as an efficient approach for the optimization of the electrocatalytic performance of the electrocatalyst [200]. Ren et al. assembled the two-electrode electrolyzer using an amorphous (Ni, Fe)OOH and MoN4 as anode and cathode, which delivers 500 and 1000 mA cm−2 when the cell voltages are 1.586 and 1.657 V respectively (Fig. 15g and h). Furthermore, the electrolyzer sustains its outperforming OWS performance for 40 h at industrial-relevant current densities (Fig. 15i). The incorporation of guest atoms/species into the host material represents an efficient approach for tuning the composition, electronic structure, and architecture of the electrocatalyst, which is directly related to the optimization of the electrocatalytic performance of the catalysts. Alloying other elements, doping heteroatoms, and constructing atomically dispersed species on the support material are typically applied in the rational design of efficient electrocatalysts. Yin et al. [55] adopted the alloying strategy to prepare the FeIr alloy, which delivers the current densities of 10, 500, 1000, 2000, and 3500 mA cm−2 at the overpotentials of 6.2, 125, 204, 336, and 471 mV, respectively for the HER process (Fig. 16 a). The electrocatalyst also exhibits excellent OER performance with overpotentials of 200, 300, and 350 mV to achieve the current densities of 20, 500, and 1000 mA cm−2, respectively, in the alkaline electrolyte (Fig. 16b). As a result, the electrocatalyst requires 1.48 and 1.73 V to reach 10 and 500 mA cm−2 and shows outstanding stability for over 500 h at the current density of 150 mA cm−2 (Fig. 16c). Doping the phosphorus into the inverse spinel Fe3O4 has been demonstrated as an efficient method for the modulation of the electronic structure of electrocatalysts, which results in the optimal binding energy for the key hydrogen intermediates during the HER process, as validated by Chai et al. [68]. Further assembly of the P-Fe3O4/IF as the cathode and NiFe LDH as the anode demonstrates superior activity with cell voltages of 1.43 and 1.58 V to deliver 50 and 500 mA cm−2 in the two-electrode electrolyzer (Fig. 16d). The NiFe LDH/IF(+)||P-Fe3O4/IF( − ) electrolyzer could function for as long as 1000 h at the current density of 1000 mA cm−2 and even 25000 s at 10000 mA cm−2 (Fig. 16e). Atomically dispersed species on the substrate have been proven as promising for catalyzing small molecules into value-added chemicals, and the SACs have found their applications in various electrocatalytic processes. Manthiram et al. [143] reported the synthesis of hier-NiFe@sCNTs with atomically dispersed nickel species, which requires cell potentials of 1.53 and 1.71 V to achieve current densities of 50 and 500 mA cm−2 in the two-electrode device (Fig. 16f). Further electrochemical evaluation indicates its excellent stability for as long as 32 h at high energy densities, promising its potential for large-scale application in the future (Fig. 16g). To get a better understanding of the recent progress achieved in the rational design of high-performance electrocatalysts operating at industrial-relevant current densities, a summary is offered in Table 3 . 6 Conclusions and outlook As a low-carbon energy carrier, hydrogen plays a vital role in decarbonizing the hard-to-abate sections, and unprecedented momentum has been devoted to developing electrocatalysts with high electrocatalytic activity and long-term stability under industrial conditions. Optimized electrocatalysts with enhanced conductivity and abundance of active sites potentially accelerate the reaction kinetics due to the modulated binding strength of the key intermediates, lowered energy barrier for the RDS, and shifted rate-determining step. More specifically, the introduction of intermediate bands, variation of d-band centers, and narrowed bandgap are demonstrated responsible for the enhanced electrocatalytic performance. Although much progress has been achieved in this field, many challenges and obstacles for the at-scale deployment of green hydrogen technology remain. (1) Improved long-term stability of the electrocatalysts under industrial-relevant current densities is the prerequisite for the large-scale deployment of water electrolysis technology. As discussed in the previous sections, the feedstock cost accounts for most of the hydrogen prices, which necessitates the long-term stability of the electrocatalysts under ultrahigh current density to realize further cost cuts. Recent advances have witnessed the durability of electrocatalysts for as long as 6000 h in the electrocatalytic oxygen evolution reaction [190]. However, rare research regarding electrocatalysts for HER and OWS with comparable durability is reported, posing an important barrier for the practical application of water electrolysis technology. Furthermore, the stability of the electrocatalysts for more than years is more beneficial for reducing the price of green hydrogen and thus necessitating the development of electrocatalysts with ultralong stability. (2) Further increases in the current densities for the electrocatalysts are required. We have estimated the hydrogen cost using the H2A toolkit, in which case, an ultrahigh current density of 1500 mA cm−2 is used as the default value for the evaluation of the hydrogen price, which is much higher than the present reported values. As summarized, the current densities used for the assessment of the electrocatalytic performance are commonly 500 and 1000 mA cm−2, which is still below the criteria for industrial applications. Therefore, developing highly efficient electrocatalysts that can operate under ultrahigh current densities represents another notable direction for the practical implementation of green hydrogen technology. (3) Decreasing the overall cell voltage of the electrolyzers is directly related to the cost-down of the green hydrogen. The reduction of the overall cell voltage of the electrolyzers could potentially improve the voltage efficiency of the electrolyzers, which substantially lowers the energy required for the production of green hydrogen and consequently the cost of it. Recent advances have witnessed the decline of the cell voltage to around 1.50 V, which implies the possibility for further decrease of the cell potential. Strategies and approaches that can substantially lower the cell voltage of the electrolyzers are desirable for the large-scale deployment of water electrolysis technology. (4) Separation of products (H2 and O2) needs to be rationally designed for the cost-down of the green hydrogen. The current electrolyzer configuration induces the problematic separation of hydrogen from oxygen, which potentially increases the price of the green hydrogen. To mitigate the cost-up induced by the complex separation process, decoupling the HER from the OER and replacing the OER with other electrocatalytic reactions represent two typical methods for alleviating the disadvantages [231–234]. An in-depth understanding of the above-mentioned approaches and a search for other alternative strategies are desired. In conclusion, we believe that the comprehensive understanding of the recent advances regarding the optimization protocols for the optimization of the electrocatalytic performance of electrocatalysts under industrial conditions would potentially promote the water electrolysis technology towards industrial deployment. Xianwei Fu received her B.S. degree from Shanxi Datong University, Datong, China, in 2013, and a Ph.D. degree from Shandong University, Jinan, China, in 2018. Then, she joined as a postdoctoral fellow with Prof. Anlian Pan at Hunan University (2018–2020). Now, she is currently a lecturer at Henan University. Her research interests include focus on fabrication of nanomaterials and application for the environment and energy field. Ruijuan Shi received her Ph.D. degree from Nankai University, Tianjin, China, in 2020. She is currently a lecturer at Henan University. Her research interests are focused on the construction of novel organic electrode materials and their applications in rechargeable batteries. Shilong Jiao received his Ph.D. degree in material science from Shandong University. After that, he joined as a postdoctoral fellow with Prof. Yujia Zeng at Shenzhen University (2018–2020). He is currently a lecturer at Henan University. His research interests include the preparation and characterization of nanocatalysts with various defects and the relationship between structural imperfections and the electrocatalytic performance of renewable energy-related reactions. Mengmeng Li received her bachelor’s degree in school of physics and materials science from Henan Normal University in 2020. She is now pursuing her master’s degree in Henan University under the supervision of Prof. Qiuye Li. Her research interests include the controlled growth of nanocatalysts and their applications in environment/energy-related photocatalysis. Qiuye Li received her Ph.D. degree in 2008 from Lanzhou Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Science. After that, she worked at the National Institute for Material Science, Tsukuba, Japan, as a postdoctoral fellow from 2008 to 2010. Now, she is a full professor at National & Local Joint Engineering Research Center for Applied Technology of Hybrid Nanomaterials, Henan University. Her research interests are synthesis of functional nanomaterials, and their photoelectrocatalysis application in energy and environment.

coredata.dc:description: The green hydrogen generation powered by renewable electricity promises the potential decarbonization of the hard-to-abate sector and is essential for the fulfillment of the Paris Agreement that attempts to limit the global average temperature rise in the range of 1.5–2.0 °C above the pre-industrial level by the end of this century. Tremendous efforts have been devoted to the optimization of the electrocatalytic performance of the catalysts under industrial-relevant current densities via rational structure design, which induces a preferential electron distribution that favors the adsorption/desorption behavior of the key intermediates, thus accelerating the reaction kinetics. In this review, a brief introduction of the current energy status will be first presented to necessitate the importance of green hydrogen. Followed by the basic concepts and fundamental understanding of the reaction mechanisms, we present efficient strategies for the enhancement of the electrocatalytic performance of the catalysts to meet the rigorous requirement under industrial conditions and the in-depth understanding behind the reinforcement will be briefly discussed next. Then the recent advances regarding the rational design of electrocatalysts operating at an industrial scale will be summarized. Finally, the challenges and perspectives in this thriving field will be proposed from our point of view.
